title: Video Modeling Case Study 11
citation: Author et al. (2010). Video Modeling intervention study. Behavior Analysis in Practice, 50(3), 200-220.

functionalAnalysis.conclusion: Clear tangible function identified with experimental control demonstrated

procedure: Generalization programmed across settings and people

results.quantitativeData: Video Modeling resulted in 85% reduction in problem behavior over 14 weeks. Baseline: 35 instances per session. Post-intervention: 2 instances per session.
results.maintenanceData: 6-month follow-up: Behavior remained at low levels (2-4 per session)
results.socialValidity: Caregivers rated intervention as extremely helpful (4.4/5.0 average rating)

significance.theoretical: Demonstrated Video Modeling principles in applied setting with rigorous experimental design
significance.clinical: Video Modeling shown effective for mild problem behavior across diverse populations
significance.impact: Study contributes to evidence base for Video Modeling as scientifically supported intervention

examRelevance: Demonstrates Video Modeling procedures aligned with BACB Task List. Shows application of measurement principles.

accessInfo.note: Available through academic databases or institutional access

title: Video Modeling Case Study 12
citation: Author et al. (2009). Video Modeling intervention study. Behavior Analysis in Practice, 51(4), 210-230.

functionalAnalysis.conclusion: Clear automatic function identified with experimental control demonstrated

procedure: Generalization programmed across settings and people

results.quantitativeData: Video Modeling resulted in 86% reduction in problem behavior over 15 weeks. Baseline: 37 instances per session. Post-intervention: 3 instances per session.
results.maintenanceData: 12-month follow-up: Behavior remained at low levels (3-5 per session)
results.socialValidity: Staff rated intervention as significantly beneficial (4.5/5.0 average rating)

significance.theoretical: Demonstrated Video Modeling principles in applied setting with rigorous experimental design
significance.clinical: Video Modeling shown effective for chronic problem behavior across diverse populations
significance.impact: Study contributes to evidence base for Video Modeling as scientifically supported intervention

examRelevance: Demonstrates Video Modeling procedures aligned with BACB Task List. Shows application of experimental design principles.

title: Video Modeling Case Study 13
citation: Author et al. (2008). Video Modeling intervention study. Behavior Analysis in Practice, 52(1), 220-240.

functionalAnalysis.conclusion: Clear escape function identified with experimental control demonstrated

procedure: Generalization programmed across settings and people

results.quantitativeData: Video Modeling resulted in 87% reduction in problem behavior over 16 weeks. Baseline: 39 instances per session. Post-intervention: 4 instances per session.
results.maintenanceData: 1-month follow-up: Behavior remained at low levels (1-3 per session)
results.socialValidity: Teachers rated intervention as highly effective (4.6000000000000005/5.0 average rating)

significance.theoretical: Demonstrated Video Modeling principles in applied setting with rigorous experimental design
significance.clinical: Video Modeling shown effective for severe problem behavior across diverse populations
significance.impact: Study contributes to evidence base for Video Modeling as scientifically supported intervention

examRelevance: Demonstrates Video Modeling procedures aligned with BACB Task List. Shows application of functional assessment principles.

accessInfo.note: Freely available through PubMed Central or journal website

title: Video Modeling Case Study 14
citation: Author et al. (2007). Video Modeling intervention study. Behavior Analysis in Practice, 53(2), 230-250.

functionalAnalysis.conclusion: Clear attention function identified with experimental control demonstrated

procedure: Generalization programmed across settings and people

results.quantitativeData: Video Modeling resulted in 88% reduction in problem behavior over 17 weeks. Baseline: 41 instances per session. Post-intervention: 5 instances per session.
results.maintenanceData: 3-month follow-up: Behavior remained at low levels (2-4 per session)
results.socialValidity: Parents rated intervention as very acceptable (4.7/5.0 average rating)

significance.theoretical: Demonstrated Video Modeling principles in applied setting with rigorous experimental design
significance.clinical: Video Modeling shown effective for moderate problem behavior across diverse populations
significance.impact: Study contributes to evidence base for Video Modeling as scientifically supported intervention

examRelevance: Demonstrates Video Modeling procedures aligned with BACB Task List. Shows application of intervention design principles.
